## Ctenophores - comb jellies

::: columns
::: {.column width="30%"}
- gelatinous plankonic animals
- swim with large plates of glued-together cilia
- many of their features evolved independently of other animals
- unique neuronal anatomy with syncytial nerve net

## Reefs consistently disappeared at major extinctions and were missing for millions of years

::: columns
::: {.column width="70%"}
<br>
![](images/coral/Stanley_coral_gaps.png)
brick symbols: reefs <br>
black intervals: post-extinction reef eclipses
:::

::: {.column width="30%"}
<br>

- repeated global mass bleaching
- at end-Triassic 96% of coral species
became extinct
- extended post-extinction reef eclipse (few to 10 million years)
- the implications are bleak for the future evolution of coral reefs
:::
:::
:::aside
[Stanley & Schootbrugge, 2018](https://doi.org/10.1007/978-3-319-75393-5_2)
:::

## Global decline of coral reefs

<br>
![](images/coral/Coral_decline.png){}

- up to 50% decline until 2007, more since then
- most reefs will disappear at 2 °C warming (very soon...)

:::aside
[Eddy et al, 2021](https://doi.org/10.1016/j.oneear.2021.08.016)
:::
:::{.notes}
- Erschreckende 99% der tropischen Korallen sollen verloren gehen, wenn die globale Durchschnittstemperatur um 2 °C ansteigt, aufgrund von Wechselwirkungen zwischen Erwärmung, Ozeanversauerung und Verschmutzung.
- Dies würde einen tiefgreifenden Verlust der marinen Biodiversität und menschlicher Lebensgrundlagen darstellen.
:::

## Climate tipping points

:::columns
:::{.column width=80%}
![](images/biosphere/Lenton_science.abn7950-fa.jpg){}
:::
:::{.column width=20%}

- tipping point - a self-reinforcing change beyond a threshold
- irreversible
- ice shields, glaciers, forests, reefs, ocean currents
:::
:::

:::aside
[McKay et al. 2022](https://www.science.org/doi/full/10.1126/science.abn7950)
:::
:::{.notes}

:::

## Tipping point

:::columns
:::{.column width=50%}
![](images/biosphere/tipping.png){}
:::
:::{.column width=50%}
- change of outside conditions
- a threshold is crossed
- the dynamics of the system speeds up change
- positive feedback
- uncontrolled, rapid system change
- switch to an alternative stable state
:::
:::

:::aside
[van Nes et al, 2023](https://doi.org/10.1016/j.tree.2016.09.011)
:::
:::{.notes}

:::

## Climate tipping points

:::columns
:::{.column width=70%}
![](images/biosphere/Lenton_science.abn7950-f2.jpg){}
:::
:::{.column width=30%}

- 1°C warming may already have triggered some tipping points
- positive feedbacks
- up to 15 tipping points are now active
- changes likely not proportional to warming
- particularly worrying is a “tipping cascade”
- strong, intrinsic, biogeophysical feedbacks difficult to influence by human actions
:::
:::

:::aside
[McKay et al. 2022](https://www.science.org/doi/full/10.1126/science.abn7950)
:::
:::{.notes}

:::

- even if we stop emitting now, CO~2~ concentrations remain high for centuries

## Cascading global climate endgame

:::columns
:::{.column width=50%}
![](images/biosphere/Climate_Endgame){height=550}


:::
:::{.column width=50%}
<br><br>

- could global warming result in worldwide societal collapse?
- a dangerously underexplored topic
- extreme weather, water scarcity, explitation of resources, sea-level rise, breadbasket failures, famine, mass migration and mortality, inequality, regional and global conflict, systemic financial risk, systemic financial crysis, ecological collapse, failed states etc...
- reinforcing “synchronous failures”
:::
:::

:::aside
[Kemp et al., 2022](https://doi.org/10.1073/pnas.2108146119 )
:::
:::{.notes}

:::

## The responsibility of scientists and universities

-   Caution (not to be alarmists) has merits, but excessive reticence is dangerous
- current approach is "err on the side of least drama” is irresponsible
- "Prudent risk management requires consideration of bad-to-worst-case scenarios"
-   Are we scientists not complicit if we allow reticence to obfuscate the assessment of the situation?
- "Facing a future of accelerating climate change while blind to worst-case scenarios is naive risk management at best and fatally foolish at worst."

![](images/biosphere/Canada_fire.jpg){height=300}

::: aside
[Hansen et al. 2023](https://doi.org/10.1093/oxfclm/kgad008)
:::


## {background-image="images/biosphere/Bosch-Hell.jpg" background-size="1500px"}

:::{.notes}
-
- I think the question now is whether some form of technological civilisation can be maintained longer term at least in some sheltered parts of the globe
- We should have a plan B or at least risk assessment for the event of cascading and catastrophic global collapse and consider what skills and knowledge will the next generation need the most
- for example, maybe every medical student should learn to deliver a baby and carry out an appendectomy, without electricity...

:::

## A Global Futures Initiative for Heidelberg


::: columns
::: {.column width="60%"}
- thinktank/institute, research/teaching in areas related to:
  - catastrophic risks
  - deep cuts in greenhouse gas emissions
  - enhancement of biosphere (Half-Earth principle of E.O. Wilson)
  - CO~2~ removal from the atmosphere
  - possibly solar radiation management
  - adaptation to warming, improve resilience
  - new economic models to tax externalities (extraction and waste)
  - more resilient democracies
  - global cooperation 
  - effective Earth System stewardship
  - ...
